repository.name: difit
repository.description: A lightweight command-line tool that spins up a local web server to display Git commit diffs in a GitHub-like Files changed view

nodes.bodyText:
Problem
Running npx reviewit on Node.js v20 results in a SyntaxError:
$ npx reviewit
file:///Users/sakamossan/.nodebrew/node/v20.9.0/lib/node_modules/reviewit/dist/cli/index.js:4
import pkg from '../../package.json' with { type: 'json' };
                                     ^^^^

SyntaxError: Unexpected token 'with'
    at ModuleLoader.moduleStrategy (node:internal/modules/esm/translators:118:18)
    at callTranslator (node:internal/modules/esm/loader:273:14)
    at ModuleLoader.moduleProvider (node:internal/modules/esm/loader:278:30)
    at async link (node:internal/modules/esm/module_job:76:21)

Node.js v20.9.0
Cause
The with syntax for importing JSON files is not supported by default in Node.js versions prior to v21.
Earlier versions require the --harmony-import-attributes flag.

V8 now implements the with syntax, behind the --harmony-import-attributes flag. This syntax is already supported in other server-side environments, such as Deno and Bun.

Reference: Import Attribute proposal syntax support has landed in V8 ¬∑ Issue #50134 ¬∑ nodejs/node
I believe maintaining the simple npx reviewit execution experience is preferable over requiring users to add flags.
Potential approaches:

Use fs.readFileSync: Read package.json using traditional file system methods for better compatibility
Require Node.js v21+: Update the minimum Node.js version requirement in package.json
Document flag usage: Provide instructions for using --harmony-import-attributes with older versions

What are your thoughts on these approaches?
Reference

#1
nodes.title: SyntaxError occurs when running on Node.js versions below v21

nodes.bodyText:
When starting the ReviewIt server with npx reviewit ., if port 3000 is already in use, the application tries the next available port (e.g., 3001). However, the server startup message shows the URL as http://localhost:undefined instead of displaying the actual port number. This makes it difficult to know which port the server is running on and prevents the browser from opening the correct URL automatically.
Steps to reproduce:
Start another process on port 3000 (e.g., run any server on port 3000).
npx reviewit .
Port 3000 is busy, trying 3001...

üöÄ ReviewIt server started on http://localhost:undefined
üìã Reviewing: .
üåê Opening browser...

The browser opens a URL with undefined as the port.
Expected behavior:
The server URL should display the correct port number (e.g., http://localhost:3001) when port 3000 is unavailable and a fallback port is used. The browser should also open the correct URL.
Environment:
OS: macOS 26 beta 2
Node.js version: v22.14.0
ReviewIt version: 1.1.5
Please let me know if you need any more details!
nodes.title: Port Fallback Causes "undefined" in Server URL When Port 3000 Is Busy.

nodes.bodyText:
Implement a ReviewIt MCP server so that the coding agent can call ReviewIt autonomously and send review requests to the user.
After the user finishes the review and closes the tab, the review content should be printed to standard output, enabling the coding agent to continue addressing the review immediately.
nodes.title: Implement ReviewIt MCP Server

nodes.bodyText:
Description
reviewit currently fails to display diffs on systems where a custom Git diff.external tool, such as difftastic, is configured in the user's .gitconfig.
Even when git status clearly shows unstaged modifications, reviewit reports that no differences were found. This appears to happen because the application's internal diff parser receives human-readable, formatted output from the custom tool instead of the standard machine-readable unified diff format it expects.
Root Cause Analysis
The GitDiffParser uses simple-git to execute git diff. This git diff command respects the user's Git configuration. If diff.external is set (e.g., diff.external = difft --background=light), Git pipes the output through this external tool.
The current parser is designed for the standard unified diff format and cannot interpret the structured output from tools like difftastic, which likely causes the parsing to fail and results in an empty diff.
Steps to Reproduce


Configure a custom diff tool.
Bash
brew install difftastic

git config --global diff.external "difft --background=light"



Make a file modification in any Git repository.
Bash
echo "# test change" >> README.md



Run reviewit.
Bash
npx reviewit .



Observe the output. The terminal shows "No differences found" even though unstaged changes exist.
Example Terminal Output
$ git status
On branch main
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/main'.

Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git restore <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
        modified:   README.md

no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")

$ npx reviewit .

üöÄ ReviewIt server started on http://localhost:3000
üìã Reviewing: .

‚ö†Ô∏è  No differences found. Browser will not open automatically.
   Server is running at http://localhost:3000 if you want to check manually.



Suggested Solution
To make reviewit more robust, it's thought that ensuring it always requests a standard unified diff from Git would be an effective solution. This would make the tool independent of any user's local configuration.
This can likely be achieved by modifying the parseDiff method in src/server/git-diff.ts to always include flags that bypass external diff tools. Adding these options directly to the diffArgs array seems to be the most concise approach.
TypeScript
// File: src/server/git-diff.ts

// ... inside the parseDiff method of the GitDiffParser class

      if (ignoreWhitespace) {
        diffArgs.push('-w');
      }

      // By adding these flags directly to diffArgs, it is thought that
      // reviewit can be made resilient to custom user configurations.
      diffArgs.push('--no-ext-diff', '--color=never');

      // Use the same modified diffArgs for both calls
      const diffSummary = await this.git.diffSummary(diffArgs);
      const diffRaw = await this.git.diff(diffArgs);

      const files = this.parseUnifiedDiff(diffRaw, diffSummary.files);

// ...

This approach is expected to resolve the issue at its source, allowing reviewit to function correctly without requiring users to create wrapper scripts or modify their environment.
nodes.title: Fails to Parse Diff on Systems Using a Custom `diff.external` Tool

nodes.bodyText:
Summary
Commit 66e4708 removed the ability to position the cursor by clicking on diff lines. This feature is essential for efficient code review workflows and should be restored.
Use Case
When reviewing diffs (especially those with large additions), I typically:

Scroll through the diff using the mouse to get an overview
Click on a specific line to position the cursor there
Use keyboard shortcuts (n/p) to navigate between diff chunks from that position

Without the click-to-position functionality, the cursor remains at its original position after scrolling. This causes unexpected behavior when using n/p shortcuts, as they navigate from the old cursor position rather than the currently visible area. The workaround of manually navigating to the desired position defeats the purpose of having both mouse and keyboard navigation.
Additional Context
This click-to-focus functionality exists in the original Gerrit interface that difit was inspired by, demonstrating its importance in code review workflows.
Proposed Solution
If the removal was due to concerns about:

Unwanted cursor movement being annoying
Interference with text selection/copying

We can explore solutions that minimize these issues while preserving the core functionality:

Only move cursor on click when not dragging (to preserve text selection)
Add a modifier key requirement (e.g., Ctrl+Click) to position cursor
Make the feature configurable in settings
Add visual feedback to make cursor positioning more intentional

I'm happy to discuss implementation details and contribute a PR if needed. The goal is to find a balance that preserves this essential navigation feature while addressing any usability concerns.
nodes.title: Request to restore cursor positioning on mouse click functionality
Enforce memoization via lint for performance
Make it easy to swap out file viewers based on language or file type

nodes.title: test cca

nodes.bodyText:
First, let me say thank you for making this wonderful tool. I just discovered it today and it perfectly fills a gap that has been bothering me for some time: providing batched code review feedback to LLMs from a side-by-side diff. Your project deserves way more stars.
Now, for the report. When difit exits, I notice that the filename and line number for each comment is reported as undefined, which I assume is what JS null renders as into a string. Example:
üìù Comments from review session:
==================================================
undefined:Lundefined
Might want to allow `WebFetch` and `WebSearch` for research on packages.
=====
undefined:Lundefined
We can drop the parenthetical "refer to" remarks, since the agent may not know about the other commands and will not be able to execute them, if it does.
=====
undefined:Lundefined
The `find` command does not respect `.gitignore` afaik. Not sure how useful this is. Would simply expect the `filesystem.rst` to be up-to-date.

Would be more useful to list the contents of `documentation/architecture/designs`.

By contrast, what I paste from the clipboard into Claude Code has the correct context:
  .auxiliary/configuration/claude/commands/cs-design-python.md:L2
  Might want to allow `WebFetch` and `WebSearch` for research on packages.
  =====
  .auxiliary/configuration/claude/commands/cs-design-python.md:L14-L15
  We can drop the parenthetical "refer to" remarks, since the agent may not know about the other commands and will not be able to execute them, if it does.
  =====
  .auxiliary/configuration/claude/commands/cs-design-python.md:L25
  The `find` command does not respect `.gitignore` afaik. Not sure how useful this is. Would simply expect the `filesystem.rst` to be up-to-date.

  Would be more useful to list the contents of `documentation/architecture/designs`.

Obviously, this is a very minor issue, since the clipboard actually does have the context which the LLM needs. But, I could see this as being problematic if someone was trying to use this as a Claude Code hook or ! command. (Possible timeout issues notwithstanding.)
nodes.title: Minor Bug: Nulls for filename and line number in final execution report.

nodes.bodyText:
Reproduction

Start difit

npx difit --no-open --mode=inline


Hover over the - and + lines in the diff.
The comment icon appears on each of the - and + lines.


Expected result
The comment icon is shown only on the hovered line.
Actual result
The comment icon is not limited to the hovered line; it appears on both the - and + lines.
On GitHub
The comment icon is shown only on the hovered line.
nodes.title: When mode=inline is used, two comment icons are displayed

nodes.bodyText:
The git command treats new files as though they are changes relative to /dev/null. E.g.:
new file mode 100644
index 0000000..6dde9fd
--- /dev/null
+++ b/documentation/architecture/decisions/004-subcommand-architecture.rst
You can even do, for example, git diff -- /dev/null .auxiliary/notes/cli-discussion.md, to see an existing file presented as though it is new. Would be nice if difit supported similar syntax; perhaps difit -- /dev/null <target-file> or maybe something more elegant?
Being able to perform a review on a whole existing file is useful for several reasons:

File was not previously reviewed but targeted LLM-executed edits are desired in it. (Removal of redundant content, summarization and compaction of content, expansion of content, rewording of entire sections, etc....)
Various changes to file have been reviewed during its evolution, but it needs an LLM to perform a holistic cleanup or rewrite, based on human-supplied comments.

What do you think? Beyond the scope of difit or something worthwhile?
nodes.title: Feature: Ability to display whole existing file as a new diff.

nodes.bodyText:
